name: Autopsy
useCase: Comprehensive digital forensics platform for analyzing hard drives and mobile devices. Ideal for case management and automated analysis.
steps: Install Autopsy and launch the application
Create a new case with case name, number, and examiner details
Add a data source (disk image, local drive, or logical files)
Select ingest modules: File Type Identification, Extension Mismatch, Exif Parser, Keyword Search, Hash Lookup, etc.
Run analysis and wait for ingest modules to complete
Review results in the tree view: Files, Tags, Timeline, Keyword Hits
Generate comprehensive HTML or Excel report

example.scenario: Analyzing a disk image from a suspect's laptop to find evidence of data exfiltration
example.command: Via GUI: Case → New Case → Add Data Source → Select E01 image → Enable 'Recent Activity' and 'Keyword Search' modules
example.output: Ingest completed. Found 342 web history entries, 15 keyword hits for 'confidential', 8 USB device connections, and 23 files with timestamps matching incident window.
example.interpretation: Timeline shows USB drive connected 10 minutes before suspicious network traffic. Files matching 'confidential' keyword were accessed and potentially copied to external device.

name: FTK Imager
useCase: Industry-standard tool for creating forensic images and previewing evidence without mounting. Essential for evidence preservation.
steps: Launch FTK Imager with administrator privileges
File → Create Disk Image
Select source type: Physical Drive, Logical Drive, or Image File
Choose destination image format: E01 (Expert Witness), DD (Raw), or AFF
Configure compression level and image fragmentation size
Add case information and examiner details (embedded in E01)
Verify image with hash comparison after acquisition

example.scenario: Creating a forensic image of a 500GB hard drive from a seized computer
example.command: File → Create Disk Image → Physical Drive → \\.\PhysicalDrive1 → E01 format → Compression: 6 → Fragment size: 2GB
example.output: Image creation completed: 500GB → 342GB compressed. MD5: 5d41402abc4b2a76b9719d911017c592. Verification: PASS. Time: 3h 42m.
example.interpretation: Forensically sound image created with 32% compression. Hash verification confirms bit-for-bit accuracy. Evidence preserved without modification to original drive.

name: Volatility
useCase: Advanced framework for analyzing RAM dumps to uncover running processes, network connections, and malware in memory.
steps: Acquire memory dump using DumpIt, FTK Imager, or WinPMEM
Identify OS profile: volatility -f memory.raw imageinfo
List running processes: volatility -f memory.raw --profile=Win10x64 pslist
Scan for hidden processes: volatility -f memory.raw --profile=Win10x64 psscan
Extract network connections: volatility -f memory.raw --profile=Win10x64 netscan
Dump suspicious process: volatility -f memory.raw --profile=Win10x64 procdump -p [PID] -D ./output
Analyze command history, DLLs, and registry hives as needed

pros: Can detect rootkits and advanced malware
cons: Can be slow on large memory dumps

example.scenario: Investigating a compromised server with suspected malware injection
example.output: Process: svchost.exe Pid: 2847 | Address: 0x7ff6a2e0000 | Protection: PAGE_EXECUTE_READWRITE | MZ Header found | Suspicious memory region with embedded PE file
example.interpretation: Detected code injection in svchost.exe. Executable code in unusual memory region with RWX permissions. MZ header indicates injected PE. High confidence malware indicator.

name: Wireshark
useCase: Packet capture and protocol analysis for investigating network-based attacks, data exfiltration, and malware communication.
steps: Capture packets: tshark -i eth0 -w capture.pcap or use Wireshark GUI
Apply display filters: ip.addr == 192.168.1.100 or http.request.method == POST
Follow TCP streams: Right-click packet → Follow → TCP Stream
Extract files: File → Export Objects → HTTP/SMB/FTP
Analyze DNS queries: dns.qry.name contains 'malicious'
Check for anomalies: Statistics → Protocol Hierarchy, Conversations, Endpoints
Export filtered packets or specific objects for further analysis

example.scenario: Investigating potential data exfiltration via HTTP POST requests
example.output: Found 37 POST requests to external IP 203.0.113.45:80. Follow TCP stream shows Base64-encoded payload containing database dump with customer records.
example.interpretation: Confirmed data exfiltration. Internal employee uploaded sensitive database to external server. POST content included 50,000+ customer records. Timestamps correlate with user login.

name: Sleuth Kit (TSK)
useCase: Command-line tools for low-level file system analysis, recovering deleted files, and examining disk structures.
steps: Identify file system type: fsstat image.dd
List files including deleted: fls -r -p image.dd
Extract file by inode: icat image.dd [inode] > recovered_file
View file metadata: istat image.dd [inode]
Search for strings: blkcat image.dd [block] | strings
Timeline generation: fls -m / -r image.dd > bodyfile; mactime -b bodyfile -d > timeline.csv

example.scenario: Recovering a deleted document from NTFS volume
example.command: fls -r -d image.dd | grep 'document.docx'; icat image.dd 128-144-3 > recovered_document.docx
example.output: r/r * 128-144-3: document.docx (deleted). File successfully recovered: 247KB, MD5: a3c2f1b...
example.interpretation: Deleted file found in MFT entry 128. Inode points to clusters 144-3. Content fully recovered as file wasn't overwritten. File can be opened and analyzed.

name: AXIOM
useCase: Commercial tool for comprehensive mobile device forensics including app data, deleted messages, and cloud artifacts.
steps: Connect device via USB or load backup/image
AXIOM Process: Select artifacts (messages, calls, apps, location)
Quick scan for active data or Deep scan for deleted items
AXIOM Examine: Review timeline, conversations, media
Filter by date range, keyword, or artifact type
Tag relevant evidence and add examiner notes
Generate comprehensive report with exhibits

cons: Requires regular updates for new apps

example.scenario: Extracting deleted WhatsApp messages from Android device in custody battle
example.command: AXIOM Process → Android Full File System → Select 'WhatsApp' artifact → Deep Scan enabled
example.output: Recovered 1,247 active messages and 89 deleted messages. Found 34 images in chat cache. GPS coordinates embedded in 12 photos.
example.interpretation: Deleted messages show communication between parties about asset concealment. Metadata confirms messages sent during disputed timeframe. Photos contain EXIF location data.

name: Bulk Extractor
useCase: High-speed data extraction tool that scans disk images for emails, URLs, credit cards, and other artifacts without file system parsing.
steps: Run bulk extractor: bulk_extractor -o output_dir image.dd
Review generated text files: email.txt, url.txt, ccn.txt (credit cards)
Check histogram files for frequency analysis
Use -x option to exclude scanners: bulk_extractor -x gps -o output image.dd
Enable specific scanners: bulk_extractor -e wordlist -o output image.dd
Analyze results with BEViewer (GUI tool)

example.scenario: Searching for credit card numbers and email addresses in disk image
example.output: Processed 500GB in 42 minutes. Found: 2,847 email addresses (email.txt), 93 credit card numbers (ccn.txt), 15,234 URLs (url.txt). Histogram shows top domains contacted.
example.interpretation: Multiple credit cards found in unallocated space suggest deleted browser cache. Email addresses correlate with suspect's known associates. URL histogram reveals dark web marketplace access.

name: EnCase Forensic
useCase: Industry-leading commercial forensic suite for enterprise investigations, litigation support, and incident response.
steps: Launch EnCase and create new case with case metadata
Add evidence files: physical drives, logical images, or network shares
Configure EnCase processor options: hash calculation, signature analysis, email parsing
Run EnCase processor to index and analyze evidence
Use Filters and Conditions to search for specific artifacts
Leverage EnScript automation for repetitive tasks
Timeline view for chronological event analysis
Create bookmarks and tags for relevant evidence
Generate comprehensive court-ready reports

example.scenario: Large-scale eDiscovery for corporate fraud investigation involving 50TB of email data
example.command: EnCase Enterprise: Add Evidence → Process with Email Parser → Apply keyword filters → Export PST files → Generate production reports
example.output: Processed 2.3M emails across 47 mailboxes. Identified 847 messages containing fraud-related keywords. Extracted 234 attachments matching financial document patterns. Timeline shows email correspondence correlating with suspicious wire transfers.
example.interpretation: Email evidence establishes communication pattern between executives and offshore accounts. Timestamps align with unauthorized transactions. Attachments include falsified invoices and altered financial statements.

name: X-Ways Forensics
useCase: Powerful and efficient forensic tool known for speed, low resource usage, and advanced features at a reasonable price point.
steps: Create case and add evidence (image files or physical devices)
Refine Volume Snapshot (RVS) to populate file system data
Run Simultaneous Search for keywords across all evidence
Use File Header Signature Search for file carving
Review Registry Report for Windows artifacts
Analyze file system slack and free space
Generate detailed reports with selected evidence items

cons: Interface can be overwhelming for beginners

example.scenario: Rapid triage of 20 computers seized in cybercrime raid
example.command: X-Ways: Batch add 20 evidence items → RVS all → Simultaneous Search for crypto wallet keywords → Export hits → Generate triage report
example.output: Completed triage in 3.5 hours. Found cryptocurrency wallets on 7 systems, dark web browser artifacts on 12 systems, and communication logs on 15 systems. Prioritized 4 systems for deep analysis.
example.interpretation: Efficient triage identified high-value targets. Systems with wallet files and dark web access flagged for immediate forensic imaging. Remaining systems show minimal evidentiary value.

name: Cellebrite UFED
useCase: Law enforcement-grade mobile extraction tool supporting physical, logical, and file system acquisition from thousands of devices.
steps: Connect device via USB or use UFED 4PC for computer-based extraction
Select extraction type: Logical, File System, Physical, or Advanced Logical
Authenticate if required (passcode, pattern, biometric)
Start extraction and monitor progress
Analyze in UFED Physical Analyzer: timeline, messages, calls, apps
Use Advanced Logical mode for locked iOS devices
Generate detailed reports with filtered evidence

example.scenario: Extracting data from locked iPhone in homicide investigation
example.command: UFED: Connect iPhone → Advanced Logical Extraction → Wait for passcode bruteforce (if applicable) → Extract all data
example.output: Advanced Logical extraction completed: 3,847 messages, 1,234 photos, 89 videos, 234 call logs, location history with 2,847 GPS points. Found deleted messages recovered from SQLite journal.
example.interpretation: Location data places suspect at crime scene during incident timeframe. Deleted messages show communication with victim 30 minutes before homicide. Photo EXIF data corroborates timeline.

name: Magnet AXIOM
useCase: Modern forensic platform with strong mobile, computer, and cloud artifact support. User-friendly interface with powerful analytics.
steps: Launch AXIOM Process and create new case
Add evidence sources: computer images, mobile backups, cloud acquisitions
Select artifact categories: communications, user activity, media, documents
Choose processing options: recover deleted data, carve files, analyze media
Monitor processing in real-time with progress indicators
Open in AXIOM Examine for analysis and reporting
Use Connections and Timeline views for relationship analysis
Apply filters and tags to organize findings
Generate customizable reports with evidence exhibits

pros: Strong cloud artifact support (iCloud, Google, social media)
cons: Processing can be slow on large datasets

example.scenario: Analyzing cloud data from Google Takeout in employment dispute
example.command: AXIOM Process → Add Evidence → Load Google Takeout .zip → Select Gmail, Drive, Photos, Location History → Process
example.output: Processed 15GB Google Takeout: 28,450 emails, 3,847 Drive files, 12,345 photos, location history spanning 3 years. Timeline shows 847 business hours spent at competitor's office location.
example.interpretation: Email analysis reveals forwarding company documents to personal account. Google Location History shows regular visits to competitor during work hours. Drive contains competitor's proprietary documents.

name: Rekall
useCase: Advanced memory forensics framework supporting Windows, Linux, and macOS memory analysis with live memory acquisition.
steps: Acquire memory dump or use live acquisition mode
Launch Rekall: rekall -f memory.dmp
Identify profile: imageinfo plugin
List processes: pslist or pstree for hierarchy
Scan for hidden processes: psscan
Analyze network connections: netstat or netscan
Examine loaded modules: modules or lsmod
Dump suspicious processes or memory regions: procdump or vaddump
Investigate registry hives: hivelist and printkey

example.scenario: Live memory analysis of suspected compromised Linux server
example.command: rekall --live Memory → pslist → netstat → lsmod → check_modules
example.output: Detected suspicious kernel module 'netfilter_backdoor' not in package manager database. Hidden process PID 8472 making outbound connections to 203.0.113.87:4444. Process not visible in standard ps output.
example.interpretation: Rootkit detected: kernel-level backdoor intercepting system calls. Hidden process maintains C2 connection to attacker infrastructure. Standard detection tools compromised by rootkit.

name: Redline
useCase: Free incident response tool from Mandiant for memory and file analysis, IOC detection, and threat hunting.
steps: Use Mandiant Redline Collector to acquire memory and triage data
Import collected data into Redline for analysis
Review Timeline for chronological event sequence
Analyze Processes, Services, and Network Connections
Use Mandiant IOC Editor to create custom indicators
Run IOC searches across collected data
Investigate File Download History and Browser Artifacts
Generate investigation reports with findings

pros: Free tool from leading IR firm

example.scenario: Hunting for APT indicators across 50 endpoints in enterprise network
example.command: Deploy Redline Collector via GPO → Import all data → Load Mandiant APT29 IOC → Run search
example.output: IOC hits on 7 endpoints: Suspicious registry keys, known malware file hashes, C2 domain in DNS cache, scheduled tasks for persistence. Timeline shows initial compromise 47 days ago.
example.interpretation: APT29 (Cozy Bear) indicators confirmed. Initial compromise via spear-phishing. Lateral movement using stolen credentials. Persistence via scheduled tasks and registry run keys. Data staging detected on file server.

name: NetworkMiner
useCase: Network forensic analysis tool for passive sniffing, PCAP parsing, file extraction, and host discovery.
steps: Open PCAP file or start live capture
Review Hosts tab for discovered systems and OS fingerprinting
Check Files tab for extracted files from network traffic
Examine Images tab for pictures transmitted over network
Review Messages tab for email and chat conversations
Analyze Credentials tab for captured username/password pairs
Use Sessions tab to reconstruct TCP streams
Export findings for further analysis or reporting

cons: Professional version required for advanced features
Can be slow with very large PCAPs

example.scenario: Analyzing network traffic capture from suspected data breach
example.command: NetworkMiner: Open capture.pcap → Review Hosts → Check Files tab → Export extracted files
example.output: Discovered 23 hosts. Extracted 847 files including 234 images, 89 documents, 45 executables. Credentials tab shows 12 cleartext username/password pairs. FTP session contained database dump file.
example.interpretation: Attacker exfiltrated data via FTP. Captured credentials include admin accounts. Extracted files contain customer database, source code, and confidential documents. Host fingerprinting identifies attacker system as Kali Linux.

name: KAPE
useCase: Triage tool for rapidly collecting forensic artifacts from Windows systems for later analysis. Ideal for incident response.
steps: Run KAPE with administrator privileges
Select Target modules: registry, event logs, browser history, etc.
Configure Module processing: parse with tools like RegRipper, EvtxExplorer
Specify output directory (preferably external USB)
Execute collection and wait for completion
Transfer collected data to analysis workstation
Process with forensic tools (Autopsy, X-Ways, Timeline Explorer)

example.scenario: Rapid triage of compromised executive laptop before sending to lab
example.output: Collected in 4m 32s: Registry hives (87MB), Event logs (234MB), Browser data (456MB), Prefetch (23MB), recent files, USB history, network artifacts. Modules parsed 847 forensic artifacts.
example.interpretation: Timeline shows initial compromise via malicious PDF. Browser history reveals visits to phishing site. USB history shows external drive connected 10 minutes before suspicious network traffic. Prefetch confirms malware execution.
